learning_outcomes.description: Identify linguistic and discourse features in communication, including those contributing to cultural and societal diversity.
Effectively apply the concepts and theories studied in the course to interaction analysis.
Critically examine academic literature on the course content.
Effectively communicate the aspects of social interaction, both in writing and verbally.

assessments.task_description:
In Weeks 2-12, in the tutorials there will be individual and group discussions of the assigned readings and data analysis.

Students will need to prepare for the tutorials by (1) having done the course readings and (2) revisiting the lecture content. Bringing your own notes is highly encouraged.

Contributions to the discussions will be marked as follows (1 mark per week):

1 mark - Student shows clear engagement with and critical understanding of the readings and the weekly content

0.5 marks - Student shows some engagement with and understanding of the readings and the weekly content

0 marks - Student does not engage and, thus, shows no to very limited engagement with and understanding of the readings and the weekly content

Generative AI & MT Statement

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
Critical Analysis

Weight: 45% (15% per analysis; your best 3 analyses out of 4 will count towards the final mark)

Due: 5 pm on Friday in Weeks 5, 8, 10 and 12.

Length: 500 words (excluding references) for written analyses; 5-7 min. for oral analyses

In Weeks 3, 6, 9 & 11, you will have access to the interactional data in the Assessment folder on Blackboard that you will need to analyse in terms of what is covered in the weeks that correspond to the analysis:

Critical Analysis 1: Weeks 3, 4 & 5- written submission

Critical Analysis 2: Weeks 6,7 & 8 - video submission

Critical Analysis 3: Weeks 9 & 10 - written submission

Critical Analysis 4: Weeks 11 & 12 - video submission

In your analysis, you will need to

  • identify linguistic and discourse features in the data relevant to the weeks indicated in the task;
  • explain those features and what happens in the data in terms of the relevant course concepts;
  • support your analysis with the relevant readings from the course (from the reading list, plus those covered in lecture and tutorial, where relevant; 3-5 references). Do not use outside-the-course additional readings.

Generative AI & MT Statement 

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.task_description:
Interaction Project 

This multi-stage assessment task is designed so that you could apply your knowledge of the pragmatics of social interaction to authentic data – a real-life phone conversation. This task mirrors real-world practices in the fields such as discourse analysis, pragmatics, conversation analysis, interpersonal and intercultural communication where analysing authentic interaction is essential. 

In Week 4, you will have access to three to five 30-minute phone conversations* in the Assessment folder on Blackboard that you will have to listen to in order to become famliar with the data. In Week 6, you will need to choose one of those phone conversations that you will use for your project. The choice of each phone conversation will be limited, i.e. all the students cannot select the same conversation. This means that you need to identify more than one phone conversation of your interest prior to Week 6. The final data allocation will be made on a first-come, first-served basis via a live document. Students not present in class will be randomly assigned one of the available recordings.

*Students who wish to use the conversational data that they audio (video) record themselves will need to contact the course coordinator by Week 3. They will need to collect the data (no ethical clearance needed) by Week 5 and share it with the course coordinator to obtain the approval to use it for the Interaction Project assessment. 

IMPORTANT: Start working with the data early in the semester! Note that it is NOT a group project, which means that your extracts selection and transcriptions must reflect your own individual work. 

Interaction Project - Written Submission (40%)

Deadline: Week 13, Friday, 5 pm

Length: 2000-2400 words (excluding extracts and references)

Your written submission must include the following sections and 15-20 references (for more information, see the template on Blackboard):

  • Introduction (explanation of why it is important to research social interaction - provide examples from empirical studies);
  • Literature review (research done in relation to the identified concept + aims of this project);
  • Data description (source, participants, context, etc.);
  • Analysis & discussion (here you need to focus on 1 concept from the course that became visible in the recorded interaction): provide in-depth analyses of 2 extracts.
  • Conclusion (present a summary of your research project).

Generative AI & MT Statement 

The written task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

Interaction Project follow-up oral discussion (in-person)

Deadline: Exam Week 2

Students will need to come to an in-person oral discussion of their submitted written Interaction Project, bring a hard copy of their written submission (with notes, if needed) and, if necessary, original publications used in the submission. No devices will be allowed. The oral examination will take up to 10 minutes, will be audio-recorded and include clarification questions on:

(1) Literature review choice and details of the content of readings summarised;

(2) Data details;

(3) Data analysis claims.

IMPORTANT: If you do not come to the project follow-up discussion or fail to demonstrate your knowledge of the written submission and its completion independent of AI tools, the maximum grade that you can receive for the Course will be a 3.
